turns.content:
| Name | Affiliation | Major Works | Field of Specialty | Significant Idea or Theory | Similar Theorists | How Similar? | Contrarian Theorists | How Contrary? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Fei Xiaotong (费孝通) | Peking University (北京大学, 北京大學), London School of Economics | From the Soil, Peasant Life in China | Sociology, Anthropology | "Rural-Urban Continuum" - viewing rural and urban areas as a continuous spectrum | Ray Huang | Ray Huang also examines the rural-urban relationship, emphasizing how rural and urban economies are interconnected; Quote: "the rural-urban divide has long been blurred in China" | Saskia Sassen | Saskia Sassen emphasizes the global city concept, which may overlook the rural-urban continuum; Quote: "Global cities are strategic places where global processes are most deeply embedded" |
| Wang Hui (汪晖) | Tsinghua University (清华大学, 清華大學) | The End of the Revolution, China's Twentieth Century | Intellectual History, Political Science | "New Left" - critiquing neoliberalism and advocating for social justice in China | Cui Zhiyuan | Cui Zhiyuan shares similar concerns about neoliberalism and its impact on Chinese society; Quote: "The neoliberal model is not suitable for China's development" | Zhang Weiying | Zhang Weiying argues for the benefits of market-oriented reforms; Quote: "Market-oriented reforms have significantly improved people's lives and economic efficiency in China" |
| Sun Liping (孙立平) | Tsinghua University (清华大学, 清華大學) | Social Transformation in Modern China | Sociology, Social Transformation | "End of Reform" - emphasizing the need for new approaches to social reform | Zhou Xiaohong | Zhou Xiaohong also explores the limitations of current reform measures, suggesting that new approaches are needed; Quote: "The reform era has reached a turning point" | Hu Angang | Hu Angang stresses the continued importance of state-led development; Quote: "China's development model is characterized by a strong, proactive state and efficient markets" |
| Pun Ngai (潘毅) | Hong Kong Polytechnic University (香港理工大学, 香港理工大學) | Made in China, Migrant Labor in China | Sociology, Labor Studies | "Dormitory Labor Regime" - the relationship between living conditions and labor | Ching Kwan Lee | Ching Kwan Lee similarly investigates the labor conditions and labor rights of migrant workers; Quote: "The export-oriented manufacturing sector is built on the exploitation of migrant labor" | Elizabeth J. Perry | Elizabeth J. Perry focuses on the role of grassroots organizations in labor rights, which might overshadow the dormitory labor regime; Quote: "Grassroots organizations have been crucial in labor rights" |
| Yan Yunxiang (晏雲翔) | University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) | The Individualization of Chinese Society | Anthropology, Sociology | "Individualization" - exploring the growing importance of individual identity | Zhang Li | Zhang Li examines how individual identity and autonomy are becoming more important in modern China; Quote: " |  |  |
reduce the list to 5 names total, including Vanessa Fong. Also there are chinese names for which you didn't list either the chinese characters or (characters unknown), please fix that.

Perry focuses on the role of grassroots organizations in labor rights, which might overshadow the dormitory labor regime; Quote: "Grassroots organizations have been crucial in labor rights" |
| Yan Yunxiang (晏雲翔) | University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) | The Individualization of Chinese Society | Anthropology, Sociology | "Individualization" - exploring the growing importance of individual identity | Zhang Li (characters unknown) | Zhang Li examines how individual identity and autonomy are becoming more important in modern China; Quote: "Individuals increasingly seek self-expression and personal fulfillment in a rapidly changing society" | Robert J. Barnett (characters unknown) | Robert J. Barnett emphasizes the role of collective identity in shaping Chinese society; Quote: "Collective identity remains an important aspect of Chinese culture and social organization" |
| Vanessa Fong | Amherst College | Only Hope, Paradise Redefined | Anthropology, Education | "One-Child Generation" - the social and psychological impact of China's one-child policy | Susan Greenhalgh (characters unknown) | Susan Greenhalgh also explores the consequences of the one-child policy on Chinese society; Quote: "The one |  |  |
list the table just for vanessa fong

| Name | Affiliation | Major Works | Field of Specialty | Significant Idea or Theory | Similar Theorists | How Similar? | Contrarian Theorists | How Contrary? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Vanessa Fong | Amherst College | Only Hope, Paradise Redefined | Anthropology, Education | "One-Child Generation" - the social and psychological impact of China's one-child policy | Susan Greenhalgh (characters unknown) | Susan Greenhalgh also explores the consequences of the one-child policy on Chinese society; Quote: "The one-child policy has created unique social dynamics and challenges for the younger generation" | Martin K. Whyte (characters unknown) | Martin K. Whyte focuses on the adaptability of Chinese families to social changes, which might downplay the specific impact of the one-child policy; Quote: "Chinese families have shown remarkable resilience and adaptability in the face of rapid social change" |

create a table about the books published by Vanessa fong. Here are the column titles and what information they include - title, title of the book, publisher - name of publisher, year published - the year published, number of pages - number of pages, major idea #1 - a description of a major idea from the book, major idea #2 - another major idea from the book, similar theorist - the names of one or more theorists who would largely agree with these ideas, including the names of books of theirs and quotes from the books showing this agreement, then contrarian theorists - the names of one or more theorists who would largely disagree with these ideas, including the names of books of theirs and quotes from the books showing this disagreement

| Title | Publisher | Year Published | Number of Pages | Major Idea #1 | Major Idea #2 | Similar Theorist | Contrarian Theorist |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Only Hope | Stanford University Press | 2004 | 296 | The psychological impact of the one-child policy on China's "one-child generation" | The shaping of aspirations, educational choices, and future plans by the one-child policy | Susan Greenhalgh - Book: "Governing China's Population: From Leninist to Neoliberal Biopolitics" - Quote: "The one-child policy has significantly influenced Chinese society, particularly the younger generation's educational and social choices" | Martin K. Whyte - Book: "Myth of the Social Volcano" - Quote: "The one-child policy's social impact should not be overestimated, as Chinese families have shown remarkable resilience and adaptability in the face of rapid social change" |
| Paradise Redefined | Stanford University Press | 2011 | 256 | The role of transnational experiences in shaping Chinese youth identity and aspirations | The complexity and diversity of Chinese returnees' experiences and choices | Aihwa Ong - Book: "Flexible Citizenship" - Quote: "Transnational experiences and global mobility contribute to the formation of new identities and aspirations among Chinese youth" | Xiang Biao - Book: "Global 'Body Shopping': An Indian Labor System in the Information Technology Industry" - Quote: "The transnational experiences of Chinese returnees should be viewed within the larger context of global labor migration" |
